block.p: Wolfowitz Now Negotiating Terms for His Resignation After six weeks of combating efforts to oust him as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz began to negotiate the terms of his possible resignation, in return for the bank dropping or softening the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said.

Unity Fractures in Gaza Gaza City was shuttered and 19 Palestinians were killed as gunmen took over rooftops and top-floor apartments during fighting between Fatah and Hamas as their unity government continued to fracture.

Land Seizure in Venezuela President Hugo Chávez is carrying out what may become the largest forced land redistribution in Venezuela's history, building utopian farming villages for squatters, lavishing money on new cooperatives and sending army commando units to supervise seized estates.

Senate Rejects Bill on Iraq War Congressional Democratic leaders signaled they were ready to give ground to end an impasse with President Bush over war spending after the Senate soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq beginning next spring. A16

Four days into a manhunt for three American soldiers abducted in Yusufiya, Iraq, military officials said they had detained several residents who confessed to taking part in the attack and recovered equipment that might have belonged to the soldiers.

Prince Harry Kept From Iraq After weeks of speculation about the risks to him and the soldiers under his command, Britain announced that Prince Harry would not be heading out with his regiment when it deploys to the Basra region of Iraq. A17

Exposure to Nerve Gas May Have Hurt Troops Scientists working with the Defense Department have found evidence that a low-level exposure to sarin nerve gas -- the kind experienced by more than 100,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf war of 1991 -- could have caused lasting brain damage in former service members.

Efforts to Cut Energy Use A coalition of 16 of the world's biggest cities, five banks, one former president and companies and groups that modernize aging buildings pledged to investments of billions of dollars to cut urban energy use and releases of gases linked to global warming.

Democrats Agree on Budget House and Senate Democratic leaders reached agreement on a $2.9 trillion budget for 2008 that envisions a return to budget surpluses by 2012 and assumes that some of President Bush's tax cuts will expire.

Shelters for Gay Youths A small number of shelters for gay youths have opened nationwide in the past four years, reflecting an increasing awareness among child welfare advocates of the disproportionately high number of gay youths in the homeless population and the special problems they face.
Racial Generation Gap Emerges With the number of nonwhite Americans above 100 million, demographers are identifying an emerging racial generation gap.

Students Improve in History Federal officials reported that students in 4th, 8th and 12th grade scored higher on an American history test than they did five years earlier, although more than half of high school seniors still showed poor command of basic facts. A19

26 Acres in Manhattan On the Auction Block Soon Developers will soon have a chance to bid for the rights to develop the largest building site left in Manhattan, 26 acres on the Far West Side, where the Bloomberg administration envisions the equivalent of five Empire State Buildings rising on $1 billion worth of concrete pillars over a bustling railyard. A1

New Wheels for City Police Ten two-wheeled Segways are to be deployed as New York Police Department patrol vehicles on pathways and boardwalks in parks, at beaches and at stadiums, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. B1

Pact on New Felonies New York State lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer said they had agreed to make sex and labor trafficking felonies, breaking a deadlock on an issue many thought should have been resolved long ago. B1
A Health Care Warranty Taking a cue from the makers of consumer products, Geisinger Health System is taking a new approach to surgery by guaranteeing its workmanship.

Hewlett's Gamble Pays Off Hewlett-Packard's effort to transform its personal computers from low-margin commodities into more stylish devices has started to pay off. The company announced a revenue increase of 12.7 percent from the period a year earlier.
Yolanda King The eldest child of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and an actor and motivational speaker, she was 51. B7

Columns: Atul Gawande, Nicholas D. Kristof.
